entry.title: Help Navigate Robots
entry.content:
import numpy as np
import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
from sklearn.model_selection import train_test_split
from sklearn.ensemble import RandomForestClassifier
from sklearn import metrics
from sklearn.preprocessing import LabelEncoder
from sklearn.metrics import confusion_matrix

df = pd.read_csv("X_train.csv")
df2 = pd.read_csv("y_train.csv")

df.head()

Feature Engineering 

df['orientation_T'] = (df['orientation_X']**2 + df['orientation_Y']**2 +
                               df['orientation_Z']**2)**0.5
df['linear_acceleration_T'] = (df['linear_acceleration_X']**2 + df['linear_acceleration_Y']**2 +
                               df['linear_acceleration_Z']**2)**0.5
df['angular_velocity_T'] = (df['angular_velocity_X']**2 + df['angular_velocity_Y']**2 +
                               df['angular_velocity_Z']**2)**0.5

df_agg = df.groupby(['series_id']).agg({'orientation_X': ['mean', min, max,sum],
                                       'orientation_Y': ['mean', min ,max,sum],
                                       'orientation_Z': ['mean', min ,max,sum],

entry.title: NFL Score Prediction
entry.content:
This is a work in progress, something fun to do for a sport I'm interested in. Go Browns!

import numpy as np
import pandas as pd
import seaborn as sns
from sklearn.model_selection import train_test_split
from sklearn.ensemble import RandomForestClassifier
from sklearn import metrics

df = pd.read_csv("C:/NFL Prediction/Data Raw/season18.csv",index_col=0)

df.head()
GameID date home away homescore awayscore
1 2018090600 2018-09-06 PHI ATL 18 12
2 2018090900 2018-09-09 BAL BUF 47 3
3 2018090907 2018-09-09 NYG JAX 15 20
4 2018090906 2018-09-09 NO TB 40 48
5 2018090905 2018-09-09 NE HOU 27 20

Work out who won each game and create a record for each game and team combination 

df['homewin'] = np.where(df['homescore']> df['awayscore'],1,0)
df['awaywin'] = np.where(df['homescore']< df['awayscore'],1,0)

df.head()
GameID date home away homescore awayscore homewin awaywin
1 2018090600 2018-09-06 PHI ATL 18 12 1 0
2 2018090900 2018-09-09 BAL BUF 47 3 1 0
3 2018090907 2018-09-09 NYG JAX 15 20 0 1
4 2018090906 2018-09-09 NO TB 40 48 0 1
5 2018090905 2018-09-09 NE HOU 27 20 1 0 
home = df.drop(['awaywin'],axis=1)

home = home.rename(columns={'home':'team','homescore':'PF','awayscore':'PA','homewin':'win','away':'opponent'})

home.head()
GameID date team opponent PF PA win
1 2018090600 2018-09-06 PHI ATL 18 12 1
2 2018090900 2018-09-09 BAL BUF 47 3 1
3 2018090907 2018-09-09 NYG JAX 15 20 0
4 2018090906 2018-09-09 NO TB 40 48 0
5 2018090905 2018-09-09 NE HOU 27 20 1 
home['hometeam'] = 1 

home.tail()
GameID date team opponent PF PA win hometeam
252 2018123000 2018-12-30 BAL CLE 26 24 1 1
253 2018123014 2018-12-30 LA SF 48 32 1 1
254 2018123009 2018-12-30 PIT CIN 16 13 1 1
255 2018123015 2018-12-30 SEA ARI 27 24 1 1
256 2018123011 2018-12-30 TEN IND 17 33 0 1 
away = df.drop(['homewin'],axis=1)
away = away[['GameID','date','away','home','awayscore','homescore','awaywin']]
away = away.rename(columns={'away':'team','awayscore':'PF','homescore':'PA','awaywin':'win','home':'opponent'})
away['hometeam'] = 0
away.head()
GameID date team opponent PF PA win hometeam
1 2018090600 2018-09-06 ATL PHI 12 18 0 0
2 2018090900 2018-09-09 BUF BAL 3 47 0 0
3 2018090907 2018-09-09 JAX NYG 20 15 1 0
4 2018090906 2018-09-09 TB NO 48 40 1 0
5 2018090905 2018-09-09 HOU NE 20 27 0 0 
scores = pd.concat([home,away])

scores.shape

(512, 8)
scores = scores.sort_values(['team','date'])
scores = scores.reset_index(drop=True)

scores.head()
GameID date team opponent PF PA win hometeam
0 2018090909 2018-09-09 ARI WAS 6 24 0 1
1 2018091609 2018-09-16 ARI LA 0 34 0 0
2 2018092311 2018-09-23 ARI CHI 14 16 0 1
3 2018093008 2018-09-30 ARI SEA 17 20 0 1
4 2018100710 2018-10-07 ARI SF 28 18 1 0

Create moving average score variables 

ma1 = scores.groupby('team')['PF'].shift().rolling(1).mean().reset_index()
ma2 = scores.groupby('team')['PF'].shift().rolling(2).mean().reset_index()
ma3 = scores.groupby('team')['PF'].shift().rolling(3).mean().reset_index()

scores['score1MA'] = ma1['PF']
scores['score2MA'] = ma2['PF']
scores['score3MA'] = ma3['PF']

scores_2 = scores_2.drop(['date_opponent','team_opponent','opponent_opponent','PF_opponent','PA_opponent','win_opponent','hometeam_opponent'],axis=1)

Create win record coming into the game 

scores_2['cum_wins'] = scores.groupby('team')['win'].transform(lambda x: x.cumsum().shift())
scores_2['cum_PF'] = scores.groupby('team')['PF'].transform(lambda x: x.cumsum().shift())
scores_2['cum_PA'] = scores.groupby('team')['PA'].transform(lambda x: x.cumsum().shift())
scores_2['cum_games'] = scores.groupby('team').cumcount()
scores_2['cum_wins'] = scores_2['cum_wins'].fillna(0)
scores_2['win_pct'] = scores_2['cum_wins']/scores_2['cum_games']

entry.title: March Madness 2020
entry.content:
This tournament was cancelled due to COVID-19 so I have stopped development

import pandas as pd
import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import sklearn
from sklearn.model_selection import train_test_split
from sklearn.linear_model import LogisticRegression
from sklearn.metrics import confusion_matrix

sub = pd.read_csv('./MSampleSubmissionStage1_2020.csv')

sub.info()

<class 'pandas.core.frame.DataFrame'>
RangeIndex: 11390 entries, 0 to 11389
Data columns (total 2 columns):
ID      11390 non-null object
Pred    11390 non-null float64
dtypes: float64(1), object(1)
memory usage: 133.5+ KB

sub['Season'] = sub['ID'].str[:4]
sub['LowTeamID'] = sub['ID'].str[5:9]
sub['HighTeamID'] = sub['ID'].str[10:]

sub.head()

Regular Season Data 

RSR = pd.read_csv('./MRegularSeasonCompactResults.csv')

RSR.info()

dtypes: int64(7), object(1)
memory usage: 9.2+ MB

RSR = RSR[RSR['Season']>=2015]

RSR.info()

<class 'pandas.core.frame.DataFrame'>

Data columns (total 8 columns):

SeasonWins = RSR.groupby(['Season','WTeamID'],as_index=False)['DayNum'].count().rename(columns={'DayNum':'Wins'})
SeasonLosses = RSR.groupby(['Season','LTeamID'],as_index=False)['DayNum'].count().rename(columns={'DayNum':'Losses'})

SeasonRecord = pd.merge(SeasonWins,SeasonLosses,left_on=['Season','WTeamID'],right_on=['Season','LTeamID'])

SeasonRecord['Pct'] = SeasonRecord['Wins']/(SeasonRecord['Wins']+SeasonRecord['Losses'])

PSR = PSR[PSR['Season']>=2015]
PSR['LowTeamID'] = np.where(PSR['LTeamID']<PSR['WTeamID'],PSR['LTeamID'],PSR['WTeamID'])
PSR['HighTeamID'] = np.where(PSR['LTeamID']<PSR['WTeamID'],PSR['WTeamID'],PSR['LTeamID'])

df = pd.DataFrame(PSR[['Season','LowTeamID','HighTeamID','LowTeamWin']])

df = pd.merge(df,SeasonRecord[['Season','LTeamID','Pct']],how='left',left_on=['Season','LowTeamID'],right_on=['Season','LTeamID'])

df = pd.merge(df,SeasonRecord[['Season','LTeamID','Pct']],how='left',left_on=['Season','HighTeamID'],right_on=['Season','LTeamID'],suffixes=('_low','_high'))

df.info()

df['Pct_diff'] = df['Pct_low'] - df['Pct_high']
df = df.dropna()

Model build 

x = df[['Pct_diff']]
y = df['LowTeamWin']
X_train, X_test, y_train, y_test = train_test_split(x,y,random_state=0)

clf = LogisticRegression()
clf.fit(X_train,y_train)
clf.score(X_train,y_train)

0.5991902834008097
clf.score(X_test,y_test)

0.6265060240963856
clf.coef_

array([[2.331166]])

entry.title: Titanic Prediction
entry.content:
The purpose of this project is to see the score that I can get on the Titanic Prediction Kaggle competition by creating a very simple random forest. The only thing i will do is deal with missing values, convert categorical variables to numbers and some simple feature engineering.

Load in libraries

import pandas as pd
import numpy as np
from sklearn.model_selection import train_test_split
from sklearn.ensemble import RandomForestClassifier
from sklearn import metrics

Load in the train and test datasets

train = pd.read_csv('./data/train.csv')
test = pd.read_csv('./data/test.csv')

df = pd.concat([train,test],keys=['train','test'],sort=False)

df.info()

<class 'pandas.core.frame.DataFrame'>
MultiIndex: 1309 entries, (train, 0) to (test, 417)
Data columns (total 12 columns):
PassengerId    1309 non-null int64
Survived       891 non-null float64
Pclass         1309 non-null int64
Name           1309 non-null object
Sex            1309 non-null object
Age            1046 non-null float64
SibSp          1309 non-null int64
Parch          1309 non-null int64
Ticket         1309 non-null object
Fare           1308 non-null float64
Cabin          295 non-null object
Embarked       1307 non-null object
dtypes: float64(3), int64(4), object(5)
memory usage: 108.0+ KB

df.isnull().sum()/df.isnull().count()

PassengerId    0.000000
Survived       0.319328
Pclass         0.000000
Name           0.000000
Sex            0.000000
Age            0.200917
SibSp          0.000000
Parch          0.000000
Ticket         0.000000
Fare           0.000764
Cabin          0.774637
Embarked       0.001528
dtype: float64

20% of the age variable is missing, this is a lot of data to lose so i will start by filling them with the median value. I'll ignore the Cabin field for now, it's likely to be useful as a social class identifier but needs work to make it useful. I'll one hot encode the Sex and Embarked variables including the missing values as they may have useful information.

df.Age = df.Age.fillna(df.Age.median())
df.Fare = df.Fare.fillna(df.Fare.median())

df = pd.get_dummies(df,columns=['Sex','Embarked'],drop_first=True,dummy_na=True)

df.info()

<class 'pandas.core.frame.DataFrame'>
MultiIndex: 1309 entries, (train, 0) to (test, 417)
Data columns (total 15 columns):
PassengerId     1309 non-null int64
Survived        891 non-null float64
Pclass          1309 non-null int64
Name            1309 non-null object
Age             1309 non-null float64
SibSp           1309 non-null int64
Parch           1309 non-null int64
Ticket          1309 non-null object
Fare            1309 non-null float64

This submission received an accuracy score of 0.75598, it's in the top 85%! Not so great but a point to start from.

Feature Engineering

Age is the second most important variable in the baseline model and 20% of the values were missing. I used the median of the whole dataset to fill in these values however I think it's worthwhile looking to see if another variable is a good predictor of age to give a better estimation.
